head.title: How Anti-Abortion Rhetoric Hurts the Patient; Vulnerable Clinics

hedline.hl1: How Anti-Abortion Rhetoric Hurts the Patient; Vulnerable Clinics

block.p: Abortion is not "superior to other rights infringed on by violent crime" (letter, Jan 11). But there are other reasons for giving special police protection to family-planning clinics.
Abortion is not "superior to other rights infringed on by violent crime" (letter, Jan 11). But there are other reasons for giving special police protection to family-planning clinics.

To appear welcoming to women, clinic locations are advertised, their doors wide open. Someone could walk in off the street and spray the room with bullets. This vulnerability entitles clinics to protection.
All who use the clinics are at risk -- including those seeking prenatal care, boyfriends and husbands accompanying women who seek birth control or breast exams, nurses, doctors, receptionists.

I received care from Planned Parenthood for 10 years because I could not afford a private doctor. During my last few visits, I nervously scanned the parking lot and waiting room. I now have health insurance, which frees me from those worries, but thousands do not have that luxury. DEBRA MORGAN Mendham, N.J., Jan. 11, 1995
